sen.j: 佐野 常民（さの つねたみ、1823年2月8日（文政5年12月28日 (旧暦)） - 1902年12月7日）は、日本の武士・佐賀藩士。
sen.e: Tsunetami SANO (February 8, 1823 - December 7, 1902) was a samurai and a feudal retainer of the Saga clan.
Tsunetami SANO (February 8, 1823 - December 7, 1902) was a samurai and a feudal retainer of the Saga clan.
Tsunetami SANO (February 8, 1823 - December 7, 1902) was a samurai and a feudal retainer of the Saga clan.

sen.j: 明治期には元老院 (日本)議員となる。
sen.e: He became a councilor of Genroin (the Chamber of Elders) in Meiji period.
He became a councilor of Genroin (the Chamber of Elders) in Meiji period.
He became a councilor of Genroin (the Chamber of Elders) in Meiji period.

sen.j: 日本赤十字社の創始者。
sen.e: He was a founder of Japanese Red Cross Society.
He was a founder of the Japanese Red Cross Society.
He was a founder of the Japanese Red Cross Society.

sen.j: 官職は枢密顧問官、農商務大臣、大蔵卿。
sen.e: He filled government posts including a privy councilor, the Minister of Agriculture, Commerce and Industry, and Okura-kyo (Minister of the Treasury).
He filled government posts including a privy councilor, the Minister of Agriculture, Commerce and Industry, and Okura-kyo (Minister of the Treasury).
He filled government posts including a privy councilor, the Minister of Agriculture, Commerce and Industry, and Okura-kyo (Minister of the Treasury).

sen.j: 勲等は勲一等旭日桐花大綬章。
sen.e: He received a Medal for Merit, Grand Cordon of the Order of the Rising Sun with Paulownia Flower.
He received a Medal for Merit, Grand Cordon of the Order of the Rising Sun with Paulownia Flower.
He received a Medal for Merit, Grand Cordon of the Order of the Rising Sun with Paulownia Flower.

sen.j: 爵位は伯爵。
sen.e: His peerage was a count.
His peerage was a count.
His peerage was a count.

sen.j: 称号は日本赤十字社名誉社員。
sen.e: His title was an honorary employee of Japanese Red Cross Society.
His title was an honorary employee of the Japanese Red Cross Society.
His title was an honorary employee of the Japanese Red Cross Society.

sen.j: 佐賀の七賢人に挙げられている。
sen.e: He is mentioned to seven wise men in Saga.
He is mentioned as one of the seven wise men in Saga.
He is mentioned as one of the seven wise men in Saga.

sen.j: 名は栄寿、栄寿左衛門。
sen.e: His name was Eiju or Eiju Zaemon.
His name was Eiju or Eiju Zaemon.
His name was Eiju or Eiju Zaemon.

sen.j: 子は佐野常羽。
sen.e: He had a son Tsuneha SANO.
He had a son named Tsuneha SANO.
He had a son named Tsuneha SANO.

sen.j: 経歴
sen.e: Career
Career
Career

sen.j: 佐賀藩士下村三郎左衛門（充贇）の5男として佐賀（肥前国佐賀郡早津江村 現・佐賀市）に生まれる。
sen.e: He was born in Saga (Hayatsue Village, Saga County, Hizen Province: present Saga City) as the fifth son to Saburozaemon (Mitsuyoshi) SHIMOMURA who was a feudal retainer of the Saga clan.
He was born in Saga (Hayatsue Village, Saga County, Hizen Province: present Saga City) as the fifth son of Saburozaemon (Mitsuyoshi) SHIMOMURA who was a feudal retainer of the Saga clan.
He was born in Saga (Hayatsue Village, Saga County, Hizen Province: present Saga City) as the fifth son of Saburozaemon (Mitsuyoshi) SHIMOMURA who was a feudal retainer of the Saga clan.

sen.j: 幼名は鱗三郎。
sen.e: His childhood name was Rinzaburo.
sen.cmt: 鱗三郎の読みについては推察です。
sen.e: His childhood name was Rinzaburo.
His childhood name was Rinzaburo.

sen.j: 1831年（天保2年）に佐賀藩医佐野常徴の養子となり、佐賀藩の前藩主から栄寿の名を授かった。
sen.e: In 1831, he became an adopted son of Tsunemi SANO, who was a doctor of Saga Domain, and he received the name Eiju from former lord of Saga Domain.
In 1831, he became an adopted son of Tsunemi SANO, who was a doctor of the Saga Domain, and he received the name Eiju from former lord of the domain.
sen.cmt: 文法を修正しました。重複する単語を変更しました。
sen.e: In 1831, he became an adopted son of Tsunemi SANO, who was a doctor of the Saga Domain, and he received the name Eiju from former lord of the domain.

sen.j: 佐賀藩校・弘道館に学び、1838年（天保9年）には江戸へ遊学、古賀侗庵に学ぶ。
sen.e: He studied in Saga hanko (a domain school) Kodokan and he went to Edo in 1838 to study under Doan KOGA.
He studied in the domain school in Saga, Kodokan, and he went to Edo to study under Doan KOGA in 1838.
He studied in the domain school in Saga, Kodokan, and he went to Edo to study under Doan KOGA in 1838.

sen.j: 1839年（天保10年）、佐賀に帰り、弘道館で考証学を、松尾塾で外科術を学ぶ。
sen.e: In 1839, he returned to Saga and learnt the study of old documents at Kodokan, and Surgery at Matsuo-juku.
In 1839, he returned to Saga and learned the study of old documents at Kodokan, and surgery at Matsuo-juku.
sen.cmt: 英国英語を米国英語に修正しました。大文字表記を修正しました。
sen.e: In 1839, he returned to Saga and learned the study of old documents at Kodokan, and surgery at Matsuo-juku.

sen.j: 1842年（天保13年）、佐野家の養女駒子と結婚する。
sen.e: In 1842, he got married to Komako who was an adopted daughter of Sano family.
In 1842, he got married to Komako who was an adopted daughter of the Sano family.
In 1842, he got married to Komako who was an adopted daughter of the Sano family.

sen.j: 1846年（弘化3年）、京都で広瀬元恭の時習堂に入門し、1848年（嘉永元年）には大坂の緒方洪庵の適塾で学び、さらに紀伊で華岡青洲が開いた春林軒塾に入門する。
sen.e: In 1846, he entered Genkyo HIROSE's Jishudo in Kyoto then in 1848, he studied in Tekijuku by Koan OGATA in Osaka and he entered Shunrinken (Medical school, hospital and accommodation in Edo period), which was founded by Seishu HANAOKA in Kii.

In 1846, he entered Genkyo HIROSE's Jishudo school in Kyoto, and then in 1848, he studied in the Tekijuku (the school of the Western studies) opened by Koan OGATA in Osaka and also entered Shunrinken (Medical school, hospital and accommodation in Edo period) founded by Seishu HANAOKA in Kii.
sen.cmt: 単語に意味を補足しました。文法、表現を修正しました。
sen.e: In 1846, he entered Genkyo HIROSE's Jishudo school in Kyoto, and then in 1848, he studied in the Tekijuku (the school of the Western studies) opened by Koan OGATA in Osaka and also entered Shunrinken (Medical school, hospital and accommodation in Edo period) founded by Seishu HANAOKA in Kii.

sen.j: 適塾では大村益次郎他明治維新で活躍する多くの人材と知遇をうる。
sen.e: At Tekijuku, he was treated with kindness from many personnel, who were actively involved with Meiji Restoration including Masujiro OMURA.
sen.cmt: 「知遇をうる」ですが、「知遇をえる」の間違いではないかと考えられます。
sen.e: At the Tekijuku, he was treated with kindness by the personnel, who were actively involved with the Meiji Restoration including Masujiro OMURA.
At the Tekijuku, he was treated with kindness by the personnel, who were actively involved with the Meiji Restoration including Masujiro OMURA.

sen.j: 1849年（嘉永2年）、江戸で伊東玄朴の象先堂塾に入門し、塾頭となる。
sen.e: In 1849, he entered Shosendojuku by Genboku ITO in Edo, and became a school manager.
In 1849, he entered Shosendojuku founded by Genboku ITO in Edo, and became a school manager.
In 1849, he entered Shosendojuku founded by Genboku ITO in Edo, and became a school manager.

sen.j: 江戸では戸塚静海にも学んでいる。
sen.e: He also studied under Seikai TOTSUKA in Edo.
He also studied under Seikai TOTSUKA in Edo.
He also studied under Seikai TOTSUKA in Edo.

sen.j: この頃に勤皇運動に傾倒。
sen.e: At Edo, he started to devote himself towards pro-Imperial movement.
At that time, he started to devote himself towards the pro-Imperial movement.
sen.cmt: 原文に忠実になるよう訳を修正しました。文法を修正しました。
sen.e: At that time, he started to devote himself towards the pro-Imperial movement.

sen.j: 藩の知るところとなり､急遽佐賀に戻るよう命じられている｡
sen.e: The clan found out about the fact and he was ordered to return to Saga in haste.
The clan found out about the fact and he was ordered to return to Saga in haste.
The clan found out about the fact and he was ordered to return to Saga in haste.

sen.j: 1853年（嘉永6年）、佐賀に帰り、佐賀藩の精煉方頭人となる。
sen.e: In 1853, he returned to Saga and became tonin (a chief) of Seirenkata (an institution established in Saga for researches and experiments of physics and chemistry).
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: In 1853, he returned to Saga and became a tonin (a chief) of Seirenkata (an institution established in Saga for researches and experiments of physics and chemistry).
In 1853, he returned to Saga and became a tonin (a chief) of Seirenkata (an institution established in Saga for researches and experiments of physics and chemistry).

sen.j: 藩主鍋島直正から「栄寿左衛門」の名を授かる。
sen.e: He received name "Eijuzaemon" from the lord of domain Naomasa NABESHIMA.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: He received the name 'Eijuzaemon' from the lord of the domain, Naomasa NABESHIMA.
sen.cmt: 文法、記号を修正しました。
sen.e: He received the name 'Eijuzaemon' from the lord of the domain, Naomasa NABESHIMA.

sen.j: 1855年（安政2年）6月に長崎の海軍予備伝習に参加する。
sen.e: In June 1855, he attended navy's pilot denshu (learning what one has been taught) in Nagasaki.
In June 1855, he attended the navy's pilot denshu (learning what one has been taught) in Nagasaki.
In June 1855, he attended the navy's pilot denshu (learning what one has been taught) in Nagasaki.

sen.j: 同年8月に幕府が長崎海軍伝習所を開設し、佐賀藩から常民ら四十八名が第一期生として参加する。
sen.e: In August same year, bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) opened Nagasaki Kaigun Denshu-sho (Japanese Naval School in Edo) and 48 personnel attended from Saga domain as member of the inaugural class.

In August of the same year, the bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) opened Nagasaki Kaigun Denshu-sho (Japanese Naval School in Edo) and 48 feudal retainers of the Saga clan including Tsunetami attended as members of the inaugural class.

In August of the same year, the bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) opened Nagasaki Kaigun Denshu-sho (Japanese Naval School in Edo) and 48 feudal retainers of the Saga clan including Tsunetami attended as members of the inaugural class.

sen.j: この頃に藩主鍋島直正へ海軍創設の必要性を説き､自ら海軍所の責任者となる｡
sen.e: Around the time, he preached to the lord of domain Naomasa NABESHIMA, a need for the foundation of navy and he became a person in charge of Kaigun-sho (navy).
Around the time, he preached to the lord of the domain, Naomasa NABESHIMA, the need for the foundation of a navy and he became a person in charge of Kaigun-sho (navy).
Around the time, he preached to the lord of the domain, Naomasa NABESHIMA, the need for the foundation of a navy and he became a person in charge of Kaigun-sho (navy).

sen.j: 1857年（安政4年）、佐賀藩がオランダから購入した飛雲丸の船将となり、翌1858年（安政5年）、三重津海軍所の監督となる。
sen.e: In 1857, he became the captain of Hiunmaru (a name of a warship) that Saga Domain bought from Netherlands and he became director of Kaigun-sho in Tsu, Mie.
In 1857, he became the captain of Hiunmaru (a name of a warship) that the Saga Domain bought from Netherlands, and the following year, 1858, he became a director of Kaigun-sho in Tsu, Mie.
sen.cmt: 訳漏れ訳漏れを補いました。文法を修正しました。
sen.e: In 1857, he became the captain of Hiunmaru (a name of a warship) that the Saga Domain bought from Netherlands, and the following year, 1858, he became a director of Kaigun-sho in Tsu, Mie.

sen.j: 1863年（文久3年）、三重津海軍所で幕府注文の蒸気鑵を製作する。
sen.e: In 1863, he manufactured a boiler, which was an order from bakufu, in Kaigun-sho in Tsu, Mie.
In 1863, getting an order from the bakufu, he manufactured a boiler in Kaigun-sho in Tsu, Mie.
sen.cmt: 文の構成を変更しました。
sen.e: In 1863, getting an order from the bakufu, he manufactured a boiler in Kaigun-sho in Tsu, Mie.

sen.j: 1867年（慶応3年）、パリ万博に参加し、パリ万博会場で国際赤十字の組織と活動を見聞した。
sen.e: In 1867, he attended Paris Universal Exposition and he found out about International Red Cross Society and its activity at the venue of Paris Universal Exposition.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: In 1867, he attended the Paris Universal Exposition and he saw and heard about the International Red Cross Society and its activity there.
sen.cmt: 文法、表現を修正しました。重複する表現を変更しました。
sen.e: In 1867, he attended the Paris Universal Exposition and he saw and heard about the International Red Cross Society and its activity there.

sen.j: オランダに行き、日進の建造を発注する。
sen.e: Then he went to Netherlands and made an order for manufacturing of Nisshin (a wooden steamship with masts in Imperial Japanese Navy).
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: Then he went to the Netherlands and made an order for manufacturing of Nisshin (a wooden steamship with masts in the Imperial Japanese Navy).
Then he went to the Netherlands and made an order for manufacturing of Nisshin (a wooden steamship with masts in the Imperial Japanese Navy).

sen.j: 西欧諸国の軍事､産業､造船術などを視察して翌1868年（明治元年）に帰国。
sen.e: He inspected military affairs, industry and shipbuilding techniques in Western countries and returned to Japan in 1868.
He inspected military affairs, industry and shipbuilding techniques in Western countries and returned to Japan in 1868.
He inspected military affairs, industry and shipbuilding techniques in Western countries and returned to Japan in 1868.

sen.j: 1870年（明治3年）3月～10月までの8ヶ月間、兵部省兵部少丞に就任し、日本海軍の基礎創りに尽力する。
sen.e: He was appointed to Hyobu shojo (Junior Secretary of the Ministry of War) in Hyobusho (Ministry of War) for 8 months from March to October 1870, and he devoted himself in establishment of a foundation for Imperial Japanese Navy.

He was appointed to Hyobu shojo (Junior Secretary of the Ministry of War) in Hyobusho (Ministry of War) for eight months from March to October in 1870, and he devoted himself in establishment of a foundation for the Imperial Japanese Navy.

He was appointed to Hyobu shojo (Junior Secretary of the Ministry of War) in Hyobusho (Ministry of War) for eight months from March to October in 1870, and he devoted himself in establishment of a foundation for the Imperial Japanese Navy.

sen.j: しかし、増田明道兵部少丞等他の海軍担当官との関係は良好とは言い難く、佐野の奮闘は空回りでしかなかった。
sen.e: However a relationship between governors in charge of navy, including a Hyobu shojo Meido MASUDA, was not a friendly one and effort of Sano failed to show results.
However, a relationship between governors in charge of navy, including a Hyobu shojo Meido MASUDA, was not a friendly one and the effort of Sano failed to show results.
However, a relationship between governors in charge of navy, including a Hyobu shojo Meido MASUDA, was not a friendly one and the effort of Sano failed to show results.

sen.j: 罷免についても同僚の船越衛は同情している。
sen.e: Mamoru FUNAKOSHI, a colleague of Sano, sympathized with his dismissal.
Mamoru FUNAKOSHI, a colleague of Sano, sympathized with his dismissal.
Mamoru FUNAKOSHI, a colleague of Sano, sympathized with his dismissal.

sen.j: 1872年（明治5年）、博覧会御用掛に就任し、日本の産業の近代化をめざすべく、同年3月に日本初の博覧会を湯島聖堂で開催する。
sen.e: In 1872, he was appointed to a Goyogakari (a general affairs official of the Imperial Household) for exhibition and he held Japan's first exhibition in Yushima Seido (Sacred Hall at Yushima) in March 1872 to modernize Japanese industry.

In 1872, he was appointed to a Goyogakari (a general affairs official of the Imperial Household) for exhibition and he held Japan's first exhibition in Yushima Seido (Sacred Hall at Yushima) in March 1872 to modernize Japanese industry.

In 1872, he was appointed to a Goyogakari (a general affairs official of the Imperial Household) for exhibition and he held Japan's first exhibition in Yushima Seido (Sacred Hall at Yushima) in March 1872 to modernize Japanese industry.

sen.j: 1873年（明治6年）、ウィーン万国博覧会事務副総裁に就任して、ウィーン万博に派遣される。
sen.e: In 1873, he was appointed to a vice-president of administration for Vienna International Exhibition, and sent to Vienna International Exhibition.
In 1873, he was appointed to a vice-president of administration for the Vienna International Exhibition, and sent to the exhibition.
sen.cmt: 文法を修正しました。重複する表現を変更しました。
sen.e: In 1873, he was appointed to a vice-president of administration for the Vienna International Exhibition, and sent to the exhibition.

sen.j: 博覧会を通じて日本の近代化に貢献し、「博覧会男」の異名を得る。
sen.e: He contributed to modernization of Japanese industry through exhibition and he received an imyo (another name) 'Exhibition Man'.
He contributed to the modernization of Japanese industry through the exhibition and he received an imyo (another name) 'Exhibition Man.'
He contributed to the modernization of Japanese industry through the exhibition and he received an imyo (another name) 'Exhibition Man.'

sen.j: 1875年（明治8年）、元老院議員となる。
sen.e: In 1875, he took office as a councilor in Genroin (the Chamber of Elders).
In 1875, he took office as a councilor in Genroin (the Chamber of Elders).
In 1875, he took office as a councilor in Genroin (the Chamber of Elders).

sen.j: 1877年（明治10年）2月に西南戦争が起こる。
sen.e: In February 1877, Seinan War broke out.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: In February 1877, Seinan War broke out.
In February 1877, Seinan War broke out.

sen.j: 敵味方の区別なく戦場で負傷した将兵を看護する赤十字社の知識を元に、「博愛社設立請願書」を政府に提出するが不許可となる。
sen.e: He submitted 'Petition for establishment of Hakuaisha (an organization founded in Seinan War and aimed for aids of the wounded, later Japanese Red Cross Society)' based on knowledge of Red Cross Society, which aid wounded soldiers regardless of enemies and allies, to government but was not permitted.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: He submitted 'the Petition for establishment of Hakuaisha (an organization founded in Seinan War and aimed for aids of the wounded, later Japanese Red Cross Society)' based on the knowledge of the Red Cross Society, which aid wounded soldiers regardless of enemies and allies, to the government but this was not permitted.

He submitted 'the Petition for establishment of Hakuaisha (an organization founded in Seinan War and aimed for aids of the wounded, later Japanese Red Cross Society)' based on the knowledge of the Red Cross Society, which aid wounded soldiers regardless of enemies and allies, to the government but this was not permitted.

sen.j: 5月に熊本で有栖川宮熾仁親王から博愛社設立の許可を得る。
sen.e: He received permission of establishment of Hakuaisha from Imperial Prince Arisugawanomiya Taruhito in May at Kumamoto.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: In May, he received the permission of the establishment of Hakuaisha from Imperial Prince Arisugawanomiya Taruhito at Kumamoto.
In May, he received the permission of the establishment of Hakuaisha from Imperial Prince Arisugawanomiya Taruhito at Kumamoto.

sen.j: 博愛社総長に東伏見宮嘉彰親王が就任。
sen.e: Prince Higashifushiminomiya Yoshiakira took office as a president of Hakuaisha.
Imperial Prince Higashifushiminomiya Yoshiakira took office as a president of Hakuaisha.
sen.cmt: 親王の訳を修正しました。
sen.e: Imperial Prince Higashifushiminomiya Yoshiakira took office as a president of Hakuaisha.

sen.j: 1878年（明治11年）、大給恒らと博愛社の総副長となる。
sen.e: In 1878, he took office as a vice-president of Hakuaisha with Yuzuru OGYU.
In 1878, Tsunetami took office as a vice-president of Hakuaisha with Yuzuru OGYU.
sen.cmt: 主語を明確にしました。
sen.e: In 1878, Tsunetami took office as a vice-president of Hakuaisha with Yuzuru OGYU.

sen.j: 1879年（明治12年）、日本美術の海外流出を防ぐために、龍池会(日本美術協会)と呼ばれる美術団体を発足し、会頭に就任する。
sen.e: In 1879, he established artwork organization called Ryuchi kai (Ryuchi party) (Ryuchi kai (Ryuchi party)) to stop outflow of Japan Art, and took office as a president.
In 1879, he established an artwork organization called Ryuchi kai (Nihon Bijutsu Kyokai [Japan Art Association]) to stop outflow of Japan Art, and took office as a president.
sen.cmt: 訳漏れを補いました。文法を修正しました。
sen.e: In 1879, he established an artwork organization called Ryuchi kai (Nihon Bijutsu Kyokai [Japan Art Association]) to stop outflow of Japan Art, and took office as a president.

sen.j: 亡くなるまで会長を務め､芸術家の保護と育成に力を尽くす｡
sen.e: He filled office until he died and devoted to protection and training of artists.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: He filled office until he died and devoted himself to protection and training of artists.
He filled office until he died and devoted himself to protection and training of artists.

sen.j: 同年10月には中央衛生会会長に就任する。
sen.e: In October 1879, he was appointed to a president of Central Sanitation Association.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: In October 1879, he was appointed to a president of Central Sanitation Association.
In October 1879, he was appointed to a president of Central Sanitation Association.

sen.j: 1880年（明治13年）、大蔵卿に就任するが、翌1881年（明治14年）の明治十四年の政変で辞任する。
sen.e: In 1880, he was appointed to Okura-kyo (Minister of the Treasury) but he resigned in Meiji juyonen no seihen (the failed Meiji-14 coup of 1881) in 1881.
In 1880, he was appointed to Okura-kyo (Minister of the Treasury) but he resigned in Meiji juyonen no seihen (the failed Meiji-14 coup of 1881) in 1881.
In 1880, he was appointed to Okura-kyo (Minister of the Treasury) but he resigned in Meiji juyonen no seihen (the failed Meiji-14 coup of 1881) in 1881.

sen.j: 1882年（明治15年）、元老院議長に就任する。
sen.e: In 1882, he was appointed to a chairman of Genroin.
In 1882, he was appointed to a chairman of Genroin.
In 1882, he was appointed to a chairman of Genroin.

sen.j: 1883年（明治16年）、大日本私立衛生会が発足し、会頭に就任する。
sen.e: In 1883, the national hygiene association Dainihon Shiri-tsu Eiseikai was launched and he was appointed to a president.
In 1883, the national hygiene association, Dainihon Shiritsu Eiseikai, was launched and he was appointed to a president.
In 1883, the national hygiene association, Dainihon Shiritsu Eiseikai, was launched and he was appointed to a president.

sen.j: 1887年（明治20年）、博愛社を日本赤十字社と改称し、初代社長に就任する。
sen.e: In 1887, he changed the name Hakuaisha to Japanese Red Cross Society and he took office as the first president.
In 1887, he changed the name Hakuaisha to the Japanese Red Cross Society and he took office as the first president.
In 1887, he changed the name Hakuaisha to the Japanese Red Cross Society and he took office as the first president.

sen.j: 子爵。
sen.e: He was a viscount.
He became a viscount.
He became a viscount.

sen.j: 1888年（明治21年）、枢密顧問官に就任する。
sen.e: In 1888, he was appointed to a privy councilor.
In 1888, he was appointed to a privy councilor.
In 1888, he was appointed to a privy councilor.

sen.j: 1892年（明治25年）、第1次松方内閣で農商務大臣に就任する。
sen.e: In 1892, he was appointed to the Minister of Agriculture, Commerce and Industry in the first Matsukata cabinet.
In 1892, he was appointed to the Minister of Agriculture, Commerce and Industry in the first Matsukata cabinet.
In 1892, he was appointed to the Minister of Agriculture, Commerce and Industry in the first Matsukata cabinet.

sen.j: 1894年（明治27年）の日清戦争や、1900年（明治33年）の北清事変で日本赤十字社は、戦時救護活動を行う。
sen.e: Japanese Red Cross Society engaged in wartime relief activities in Japanese-Sino War in 1894 and the Boxer Rebellion in 1900.
The Japanese Red Cross Society engaged in wartime relief activities in Japanese-Sino War in 1894 and the Boxer Rebellion in 1900.
The Japanese Red Cross Society engaged in wartime relief activities in Japanese-Sino War in 1894 and the Boxer Rebellion in 1900.
In 1895, he became a count.
In 1895, he became a count.
In 1895, he became a count.

sen.j: 1902年（明治35年）、東京の自宅で死去、80歳。
sen.e: In 1902, he died at age of 80 in his home in Tokyo.
In 1902, he died at age of 80 in his home in Tokyo.
In 1902, he died at age of 80 in his home in Tokyo.

sen.j: 死に際して勲一等旭日桐花大綬章が贈られる。
sen.e: Grand Cordon of the Order of the Rising Sun with Paulownia Flower was awarded upon his death.
Grand Cordon of the Order of the Rising Sun with Paulownia Flower was awarded upon his death.
Grand Cordon of the Order of the Rising Sun with Paulownia Flower was awarded upon his death.

sen.j: 墓所は青山墓地。
sen.e: His grave is at Aoyama-bochi Cemetery.
His grave is at Aoyama-bochi Cemetery.
His grave is at Aoyama-bochi Cemetery.

sen.j: 常民は、明治時代に都を関東の内陸部に位置する本庄宿本庄宿に関する諸々の情報（中山道で最大の宿場町）へ遷都する案を提出するも周囲の賛同を得られず、断念している。
sen.e: Tsunetami submitted a proposal to transfer the capital to Honjoshuku (a largest post-station town in Nakasen-do Road) located inland area of Kanto, but he gave up, as he could not obtain people's support.
sen.cmt: original文の意味が不明です。ウェブ上では「本庄宿に関する諸々の情報 (originalでは「本庄宿」が2つ続いており不自然です)」という部分が無く、こちらだと意味もとおり訳すことができるので、ウェブの「常民は、明治時代に都を関東の内陸部に位置する本庄宿（中山道で最大の宿場町）へ遷都する案を提出するも周囲の賛同を得られず、断念している。」で訳しています。ウェブでは本庄宿のリンクをクリックすると本庄宿の「本庄宿に関する諸々の情報」という項目にジャンプするので、ここに入ってしまったのではないかと思われます。
sen.e: Tsunetami submitted a proposal to transfer the capital to Honjoshuku (a largest post-station town in Nakasen-do Road) located in the inland area of Kanto, but he gave it up as he could not obtain people's support.

Tsunetami submitted a proposal to transfer the capital to Honjoshuku (a largest post-station town in Nakasen-do Road) located in the inland area of Kanto, but he gave it up as he could not obtain people's support.
